title: Ticket #1628: Update Condor's Chirp to match Notre Dame's implementation
description:
Condor's implementation of the Chirp protocol is lagging behind the implementation at Notre Dame. Many new commands need to be added to Condor's Chirp to match Notre Dame's updated Chirp protocol described here: http://www.cse.nd.edu/~ccl/software/manuals/chirp_protocol.html.

Current commands in Condor's Chirp:

  • close <decimal:fd>
  • constrain <string:expr>
  • cookie <string:cookie>
  • fsync <decimal:fd>
  • get_job_attr <string:name>
  • login <string:name> <string:password>
  • lseek <decimal:fd> <decimal:offset> <decimal:whence>
  • lookup <string:name>
  • mkdir <string:name> <decimal:mode>
  • open <string:name> <string:flags> <decimal:mode>
  • read <decimal:fd> <decimal:length>
  • rename <string:oldpath> <string:newpath>
  • rmdir <string:name>
  • set_job_attr <string:name> <string:expr>
  • unlink <string:path>
  • version
  • write <decimal:fd> <decimal:length>

Commands that I did not implement:

  • getacl <string:path>
  • setacl <string:path> <string:subject> <string:rights>
  • md5 <string:path>
  • thirdput <string:path> <string:remotehost> <string:remotepath>
  • mkalloc <string:path> <decimal:size> <decimal:mode>
  • lsalloc <string:path>

Commands that I have implemented:

  • pread <decimal:fd> <decimal:length> <decimal:offset>
  • pwrite <decimal:fd> <decimal:length> <decimal:offset>
  • swrite <decimal:fd> <decimal:length> <decimal:offset> <decimal:stride_length> <decimal:stride_skip>
  • rmall <string:path>
  • fstat <decimal:fd>
  • fstatfs <string:path>
  • ftruncate <decimal:fd> <decimal:length>
  • stat <string:path>
  • lstat <string:path>
  • statfs <string:path>
  • truncate <string:path> <decimal:length>
  • link <string:oldpath> <string:newpath>
  • symlink <string:oldpath> <string:newpath>
  • readlink <string:path>
  • access <string:path> <decimal:mode>
  • utime <string:path> <decimal:actime> <decimal:mtime>
  • getfile <string:path>
  • putfile <string:path> <decimal:mode> <decimal:length>
  • getlongdir <string:path>
  • getdir <string:path>
  • whoami (implemented, but doesn't do anything useful)
  • whoareyou <string:rhost> (implemented, but doesn't do anything useful)
  • fchown <decimal:fd> <decimal:uid> <decimal:gid>
  • fchmod <decimal:fd> <decimal:mode>
  • chmod <string:path> <decimal:mode>
  • chown <string:path> <decimal:uid> <decimal:gid>
  • lchown <string:path> <decimal:uid> <decimal:gid>

Additional Error Codes:

-12  BAD_FD:           The file descriptor requested is invalid.
-13  IS_DIR            A file-only operation was attempted on a directory.
-14  NOT_DIR           A directory operation was attempted on a file.
-15  NOT_EMPTY         A directory cannot be removed because it is not empty.
-16  CROSS_DEVICE_LINK A hard link was attempted across devices.
-17  OFFLINE           The requested resource is temporarily not available.
-127 UNKNOWN           An unknown error occurred.
remarks:
After writing pread, pwrite, and swrite I have a good idea of the time required to add a command. The majority of the commands should take no longer than a few hours at most to add. However, there are a few commands that may take a bit longer though due to my lack of knowledge about what the commands do or deciding what the commands should do in the context of Condor.

Commands that may require more time to add:

  • getacl
  • setacl
  • whoami
  • whoareyou
  • md5
  • thirdput
  • mkalloc
  • lsalloc

I will complete all the other commands first and then spend my time on these.

2010-Oct-22 16:23:02 by slauson:
Using the cctools chirp client, I've got the following commands working with condor:
  • open <host>
  • close
  • whoami
  • whoareyou <hostname>
  • cat <file> [file2] [file3] ...
  • cd <remotedir>
  • lcd <localdir>
  • pwd
  • lpwd
  • get <remotefile> [localfile]
  • put <localfile> [remotefile]
  • ls [-la] [remotepath]
  • mv <oldname> <newname>
  • rm <file>
  • mkdir [-p] <dir>
  • rmdir <dir>
  • stat <file>
  • df [-k|-m|-g|-t]
  • chmod <mode> <path>

2010-Nov-03 17:22:31 by slauson:
Using parrot with condor, I've got several simple commands to work:
  • ls
  • stat
  • mv
  • rm
  • mkdir
  • cd
  • pwd

More useful commands such as cp, less, cat, vi still have some issues with a socket being closed and then condor_write() failing. I'm currently looking into the cause of this problem.

2010-Nov-12 17:37:59 by slauson:
After a few more fixes, I got parrot and condor working together. Every command that I tried that works within parrot itself works within parrot/condor.

I implemented all of the updated Chirp protocol commands within condor's chirp, except the following:

  • getacl, setacl
    • These have to do access control lists, which cctools' Chirp uses instead of chmod and chown. From my understanding, using chmod/chown instead of getacl/setacl shouldn't cause any problems.
  • md5, thirdput, mkalloc, lsalloc
    • These all provide extra functionality within the updated cctools chirp client. I haven't found that any of these are necessary for running any commands within parrot, although I could be wrong here.

After I clean up my code a little bit, I think that this is ready for a review.

2010-Nov-29 18:37:39 by slauson:
Here's what I actually did for this ticket:
  • Implemented the additional chirp commands listed above in Condor's starter/shadow.
  • Updated Condor's C++ Chirp Client to use the new commands.
  • Updated condor_chirp.cpp to use the new commands.
  • Tested the cctools Chirp Client with Condor. It can connect to Condor via a cookie and perform various commands.
    • chirp_tool
      • open CONDOR
      • close
      • whoami
      • whoareyou <hostname>
      • cat <file> [file2] [file3] ...
      • cd <remotedir>
      • lcd <localdir>
      • pwd
      • lpwd
      • get <remotefile> [localfile]
      • put <localfile> [remotefile]
      • ls [-la] [remotepath]
      • mv <oldname> <newname>
      • rm <file>
      • mkdir [-p] <dir>
      • rmdir <dir>
      • stat <file>
      • df [-k|-m|-g|-t]
      • chmod <mode> <path>
    • chirp_get
  • Tested Parrot with Condor.
    • parrot can be used with the chirp protocol to access remote files within a job's submit directory.
      parrot tcsh /chirp/CONDOR will connect to Condor via a cookie and treat a job's submit directory as if it is the local current working directory.
    • parrot_cp can be used to copy whole files across a network.
